title-group.article-title: Free vibrations control of a cantilever beam using combined time delay feedback

abstract.p: A new multi-input single-output delay feedback controller is presented to reduce free vibrations of a cantilever beam. A linear model using the first mode is derived and used to analyze and characterize the damping produced by different delay-feedback controllers as a function of the controller's gains and delay. The stability regions and amount of damping produced by three different single delay feedback and the new combined delayed feedback are investigated. A three-dimensional figure for the new controller showing the stability regions as a function of the controller gains and delay is presented. The characteristic damping of the controller as predicted by the linear model is compared with that calculated using direct long-time integration of a three-mode nonlinear model. Optimal values of the controllers gains and delay are obtained, simulated, and compared. To validate the single mode approximation, numerical simulations are performed using three-mode full nonlinear model. The results obtained using multi-input delay-feedback controllers demonstrate an excellent improvement in mitigating the first-mode vibration.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Studying and controlling flexible structures has been the focus of numerous theoretical and experimental research studies (Tzou and Tseng 1990; Shen et al. 1998; Wang et al. 1999; Abreu et al. 2003; Alhazza and Alhazza 2004). In recent years, active and passive control strategies have been developed, analyzed, and implemented. Passive control techniques utilizing viscoelastic damping and shunted circuits have been used extensively to reduce vibrations of various dynamic systems (Mead and Markus 1969; Rao 1978; Johnson and Keinholz 1982; Hagood and von Flotow 1991; Ghoneim and Karkoub 2001).

Feedback control techniques have been proven to be very effective in mitigating dynamically induced vibrations on actual systems (Irschik 2002). For real implementations, researchers used various types of actuators for their controllers. The most common of which is the piezoelectric type. Abreu et al. (2003) designed a digital regulator for a flexible beam and implemented it using ceramic piezoelectric sensors/actuators. The feedback controller was developed using an optimal control technique. The controller was able to reduce the vibrations induced in the first mode only. Crawley and de Luis (1987) studied the effect of embedding one-dimensional piezoelectric patches inside a flexible beam. They developed an expression for the moment generated by the voltage applied to piezoceramic actuators. Tzou and Tseng (1990) presented a piezoelectric finite element approach for applications oriented towards distributed dynamic measurement and control of structures. Shen et al. (1998) presented a test bed for a control system utilized for active vibration control of a plate using piezoelectric actuators. They used a localized hybrid fuzzy–proportional–derivative controller to eliminate the local vibrations in the plate. The gains of the controller were obtained using genetic algorithms technique. Using piezoelectric sensors and actuators, Shen et al. (1999) developed an optimal-multivariable feedback controller for vibration control of a dynamic system consisting of a linear elastic plate. They used a proportional–derivative and linear quadratic Gaussian controllers with loop transfer recovery to reduce the vibrations of the plate. Kirby and Matic (1994) used genetic algorithms to determine the optimal sizes and locations of two piezoelectric actuators bonded to a cantilever beam. Pereira and Steffen (2002) used a discrete optimization technique to determine the optimal positions of the actuators along a flexible structure. Their research goal was minimizing the control effort applied to a beam-type structure. Skelton and Yousuff (1983) studied the controllability and observability of a closed-loop control system for a flexible beam using a modal cost function.

In real systems, sensors, digital circuits, filters, and actuation mechanisms introduce an unavoidable delay between the controller input and the actual system actuation. These delays can greatly change the controller prediction and performance especially for systems with very high oscillation frequencies. To overcome thisproblem, feedback control designers usually tend to use predictors to reduce the effect of the delay. On the other hand, delayed-feedback controllers accommodate these delays in their parametric delays which makes delayed-feedback controllers ideal for systems that have relatively significant delays. Using this advantage, many researches focused on the delayed feedback controllers. Olgac and Hoim-Hansen (1994) developed a tunable active vibration absorber using a novel idea of delayed-feedback resonators. The idea was first introduced on the basis of delayed-position feedback. The concept was then extended through a series of research work on time-delayed velocity feedback of torsional mechanisms (Hosek et al. 1997; Olgac et al. 1997; Filipovic and Olgac 2002). Delayed-acceleration feedback was also successfully implemented to reduce pendulation of suspended cargo on ship-mounted cranes, container cranes, structural boom cranes, and telescopic cranes (Masoud et al. 2004, 2005). Chatterjee (2008) studied theoretically the linear and nonlinear vibrations of mechanical oscillators using recursive acceleration time-delayed feedback control. Alhazza et al. (2008b) implemented and analyzed a single-mode acceleration delay feedback controller on a cantilever beam. In their analysis, they compared the results obtained using analytical linear model with those obtained using long-time integration. Owing to the existence of many solutions, they showed that the analytical method failed to predict the exact location of the optimal parameters. Furthermore, they clearly showed and explained the effect of delay-feedback on the system amplitude and frequency. The implementation of delay-feedback controller is extended by Alhazza et al. (2009). They designed and studied a multi-mode delay-feedback controller with single-input single-output (SISO) on a cantilever beam. Their results demonstrate the feasibility of such controller in mitigating the vibrations of the first and second mode. Daqaq et al. (2008) presented a comprehensive investigation of the effect of feedback delays on the non-linear vibrations of a piezoelectrically actuated cantilever beam. In their work, the linear and non-linear free responses of a beam subjected to a delayed-acceleration feedback is presented. They showed that the trivial solution loses stability via a Hopf bifurcation leading to limit-cycle oscillations. They also analyzed the effect of feedback delays on a beam subjected to a harmonic base excitations and found that the nature of the forced response is largely defined by the stability of the trivial solutions of the unforced response. In another work on nonlinear delayed-feedback, Alhazza et al. (2008a) presented a comprehensive investigation of time delay effects on the nonlinear control of parametrically excited cantilever beams. Using the method of multiple scales, they studied the system behavior under three nonlinear cubic delayed-feedback methodologies.

In this work, a multi-input delayed-feedback controller is developed to reduce the vibrations of a flexible beam using a single piezoelectric actuator. The gains and time delay of the controller are optimized using linear and nonlinear numerical analysis to obtain the maximum damping. The results are also compared with three different SISO delay controllers. The multiple frequencies and damping ratios produced by the presence of time delay are explored and simulated. The performance of the controller using parameters obtained using the linear model is compared with that using parameters obtained numerically by a three-mode nonlinear model. It is shown that by using the new methodology, the performance of the controller can be greatly enhanced compared with single-input controllers.

sec.title: 3. Single-input linear delayed feedbacks
sec.p: Delayed feedback can introduce a significant amount of damping or excitation into a closed-loop system (Masoud et al. 2004, 2005; Daqaq et al. 2008; Alhazza et al. 2008 a,b, 2009). In this section, the amount of damping produced by acceleration, velocity, and displacement delay-feedback controllers and their stability regions are calculated and compared. Considering only the first mode, a general linear form of Equation (4) with a single time-delay feedback can be written as (5) where μ is linear viscous damping, ωn is the natural frequency, and κ is the time-delayed feedback defined by (6) In Equation (6), τ is the time delay and Kd, Kv, and Ka, are the displacement, velocity, and acceleration controllers feedback gains, respectively. Assuming an exponentially damped response, the solution of Equation (5) is given by (7) where A is the oscillation amplitude, σ is the damping parameter, and ω is the frequency of the response. Substituting Equation (7) into Equation (5), separating the real and imaginary parts and setting their coefficients to zero independently leads to (8) (9) where Ψ and ϒ defined by

Equations (8) and (9) can be nondimensionalized with respect to the natural frequency of the linear system, ωn, as (10) (11) where Ψ¯ and ϒ¯ defined by
and λ = ω/ωn, ζ = σ/ωn, ν = μ/ωn, γ = τ/T, and T = 2π/ωn. For a given controller gain, K, and time delay, τ, Equations (10) and (11) can be solved for λ and ζ. It is worth noting that the initial conditions have no effect on the values of the damping, ζ, and frequency, λ calculated from Equations (10) and (11). Solving these transcendental equation introduces many solutions. Therefore, the general solution of Equation (5) using the principle of superposition can be written as (12) Investigating Equation (12), it becomes evident that the stability of the system depends on the value of the damping parameter, ζj. The system is stable for all ζ values > 0 and unstable for any ζ < 0. The boundaries of linear stability correspond to having one of the ζ values equal to zero while the rest are greater than zero. Since there exist many solutions as in Equation (12), the system behavior is characterized by the frequency corresponding to the lowest damping. To compare between the different delayed-feedback controllers, namely, displacement, velocity, and acceleration, the boundary of linear stability is found by setting ζ = 0 in the nonlinear algebraic Equations (10) and (11). The corresponding boundaries are obtained as (13) (14) (15)

Alhazza et al. (2008b) proved that for acceleration feedback, the linear model predicts accurately the boundary of stability but fails to predict the exact location of the maximum damping. To accurately predict the location of the optimal damping, the controlled and uncontrolled nonlinear EOMs are integrated numerically using three modes. The root mean square of oscillation is used to determine the amount of damping introduced into the system. The reduction in oscillations is calculated in decibels as (16) where Uc and Uu are root mean squares of the controlled and uncontrolled responses, respectively, and are defined as (17) with T is defined as the uncontrolled period of the first mode and u(t) is the first mode response calculated from Equation (4). The numerical results of the reduction, R, is used to generate three contour plots of the stability regions. These results were generated using a mesh of 500 × 500 points and are shown in Figure 2. Stable regions are represented by the shaded areas. The degree of the shading represents the value of the damping variable σ. The darker the shade is, the higher the damping is. The boder lines in Figures 2(a), 2(b), and 2(c), represent Equations (13), (14), and (15), respectively. It can be seen that the linear model predicted the stability regions with negligible penalties. From Figure 2(a), the maximum value for the reduction, R, found for the acceleration delayed feedback is Rm = −19.416 when Ka = 0.472 and γ = 0.3160. On the other hand, the maximum reduction for the velocity feedback is Rm = −23.676 when Kv = 1.072 and γ = 0.112, and for the displacement feedback is Rm = −19.073 when Kd = −0.05679 and γ = 0.3. It is worth noting that the three controllers staple areas, the amount of damping produced, and the location of the maximum damping are totally different. To compare the performance of these controllers, the optimal values of the three controllers are found and the responses are plotted in Figure 3. It can be seen that when using the acceleration feedback controller the amplitude was reduced to 40% in the first peak but it needed six periods to eliminate most of the vibrations. The acceleration feedback response consists of more than one frequency, which proves the existence of multiple solutions. These solutions make the prediction of the optimal damping using the linear model somewhat inaccurate as reported previously by Alhazza et al. (2008b). It can also be seen that the velocity feedback eliminates the vibrations after three periods with a maximum overshoot of about 20%, while the displacement controller required approximately four periods to eliminate the vibrations. These results show that the velocity delay-feedback introduced the maximum damping as compared with acceleration and displacement feedbacks. Figure 1.

sec.title: 4. Multi-input linear delayed feedbacks
sec.p: As seen in the previous section, the amount of damping is relatively limited when using single-input delay feedback. The scope of this work is to increase the amount of damping by combining two delayed feedbacks and to study the behavior of such controllers. For this purpose, a linear feedback control algorithm for a delayed position and velocity feedback signal is derived. Unlike the single-input controllers, which have one gain and delay, the proposed control method specifies different gain for each controller yet both have the same time delay. This three-dimensional problem is discussed and analyzed in details and the resulting control parameters are optimized. Considering point s3, Figure 1, the sensor displacement can be expressed as (18) and its velocity as (19) whereas the driving voltage of the piezoelectric actuator takes the form (20) with k¯d and k¯v defined as the controller gains and τ is the time delay. sec.title: 4.1. Linear analysis
sec.p: Feedback control techniques used for oscillation control are limited by the fact that they are usually sensitive to variations in parameter values, changes in initial conditions and external disturbances, and that they require highly accurate system parameter values to achieve satisfactory response. On the other hand, delayed-feedback controllers are, in general, very robust (Masoud et al. 2004, 2005; Alhazza et al. 2008b), hence, a linear controller with parameters optimized using the nonlinear model can be considered without jeopardizing its performance. Considering only the first mode, n = 1, the linearized model of the closed-loop system, Equation (21), reduces to (22)

Assuming an exponentially damped response, the solution of Equation (22) can be given as in Equation (7). Substituting Equation (7) into Equation (22) and separating the real and imaginary parts and setting their coefficients to zero gives (23) (24)

Nondimensionalizing Equations (23) and (24) with respect to the natural frequency of the linear system, ω1, results in the following two equations: (25) (26) where λ = ω/ω1, ζ = σ/ω1, ν1 = μ1/ω1, γ = τ/T, and T = 2π/ω1. Note that the solutions of the transcendental Equations (25) and (26) do not always guarantee the optimal solution of parameters λ and ζ and these solutions are independent of initial conditions. For given controller gains, Kd and Kv, and time delay, γ, these equations can be solved for λ and ζ. Since these equations are transcendental, infinite solutions exist. The general solution of this linear system, Equation (22), is obtained by superimposing the solutions of λ and ζ, and can be written as (27)

Inspecting Equation (27) shows that the stability of the system depends on the value of the damping parameter, ζj, with the system being stable for all values of ζ ≥ 0, i.e. positive damping, and unstable for any ζ < 0, i.e. negative damping, while the boundaries of linear stability correspond to ζ = 0. It can also be seen that highly damped frequencies cause the system response to decay faster, which means that the system behavior is dominated by the lowest damping frequency. To have a better understanding of such a behavior, the damping ratio ζ is parametrically plotted for λ < 5, Kd = 0.2, and Kv = −0.5 and 0.5, respectively, as shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Solution of Equations (25) and (26) for Kd = 0.2, ν = 0.01, and ω1 = 1. (a) Damping variation with delay, Kv = −0.5. (b) Frequency variation with delay, Kv = −0.5 (c) Damping variation with delay, Kv = 0.5. (d) Frequency variation with delay, Kv = 0.5.

Figures 4(a) and 4(b) show the solutions of the damping parameter, ζ, and their corresponding frequencies, λ, as a function of the controller time delay γ. These plots are generated for gain values Kd = 0.2 and Kv = −0.5. It is clear from Figure 4(a) that thesolutionlabeled 1 correspond the smallest damping.Further inspecting solution labeled 1, the values of ζ resulting in a stable solution correspond to controller time delay γ < 0.23. Although solutions labeled 2, 3, 4, and 5 are stable beyond the time delay γ = 0.23, the general solution of the system is unstable because of the fact that the solution labeled 1 loses stability, i.e. negative ζ. Careful examination of theresults in Figures 4(a) and 4(b) indicate that solutions labeled 2, 3, 4, and 5 are highly damped, and since the general solution of this system is the summation of all solutions, Equation (27), one can conclude that their effect is negligible. Consequently, it can be stated that the system behavior is governed by the lowest damping solution, which in this case is the solution labeled 1; that is (28)

Figure 4(b) shows that all frequencies decrease as γ increases except for the solution labeled 1. This solution starts at frequency λ ≈ 0.82 at γ = 0 and increases until it reaches a maximum value of about 1.33 at γ ≈ 0.18, then decreases as γ increases beyond 0.18. Considering ζ = 0.3 in Figure 4(a), only two stable solutions exist. Both solutions correspond to the solution labeled 1 and they occur at two different time delays, γ ≈ 0.033 and γ ≈ 0.14. Referring to these time delays from Figure 4(b), one can see that these solutions have two distinct frequencies, λ ≈ 0.9 and λ ≈ 1.28, respectively. To prove these findings, the time response corresponding to these solutions is plotted in Figure 5. It is clear that both solutions are decaying at the same rate, both have identical decaying envelope, yet the decaying frequencies are different. Figure 5.
Numerical solution of Equation (22) with Kd = 0.2, Kv = 0.5, μ1 = 0.01, and ω1 = 1.0.

Figures 4(c) and 4(d) show solutions of Equations (25) and (26) when setting Kd = 0.2 and Kv = 0.5. Owing to the existence of multiple stable and unstable solutions, as can be clearly seen in Figure 4(c), the system is stable for time delay, γ, ranging between 0.228 and 0.54, and unstable elsewhere. Using the same argument as with the previous case, because of the high damping associated with solutions labeled 3, 4, and 5, solutions labeled 1 and 2 are controlling the stable region. Close examination of this region shows that for time delay γ ranging between 0.228 and 0.427, the solution labeled 1 is governing the general solution with lowest damping as compared with the solution labeled 2. On the other hand, the solution labeled 2 takes over and governs the behavior with the lowest damping for time delay ranging between 0.427 and < 0.54. Referring to Figure 4(c), it can be seen that for ζ = 0.1 there exist two stable solutions that occur at two different time delays. These stable solutions correspond to solutions labeled 1 and 2, and they occur at time delay γ ≈ 0.32 and γ ≈ 0.51. Matching these time delays from Figure 4(d), one can see that these solutions have two distinct frequencies, λ ≈ 0.7 and λ ≈ 0.6, respectively. Using a similar analogy as in the previous case, it can be shown that the time response of these solutions follow exactly the same behavior as in Figure 5, i.e. they have the same decaying envelop yet different frequencies.

To complete the analysis, Equations (25) and (26) are solved for the lowest two ζ when Kd = 0.2, −1 < Kv < 1, and 0 < γ < 1. These results are three-dimensionally plotted with mesh of 1000 × 1000 and are shown in Figure 6(a). It can be seen from the figure that there are two surfaces constructing the plot. Other solutions do not contribute in this plot because of their high damping characteristics and high frequencies, which fades them out from appearing in the general solution when compared with lightly damped solutions, see Figure 4 for details. It should be noted here that the results in Figure 6(a) show all possible, stable and unstable, solutions. To make the most use of these results, only stable solutions are extracted and plotted in a contour manner as shown in Figure 6(b). This contour plot shows the stable regions, represented by the shaded areas, as function of time delay, γ and controller gain, Kv. The degree of shading reflect the value of the damping variable ζ; the darker the shade, the higher the damping. These types of figures are usually used for design and optimization purposes. Particularly speaking, this figure can be used for selecting the optimal controller gain and time delay combination for a given value of Kd, namely Kd = 0.2. It is important to mention that, because of the existence of many near-optimal stable solutions in the vicinity of the optimal solution, small deviation in the selection of the delay or gain can easily be adopted by the controller without any sudden change in the behavior. sec.title: 4.2. Nonlinear response
sec.p:
In this section, the effect of beam nonlinearities and the existence of multiple solutions on the linearly obtained damping is studied. Since there is usually more than one frequency solution in these types of analyses, it is quite possible that the lowest damping parameter ζ does not usually describe the actual damping in the system, especially when ζ1 ≈ ζ2, see Equation (12). For this reason, the full nonlinear model, using three modes, is used to generate the reduction contours, Equation (16). Quick examination shows that the damping contours shown in Figure 7 are different from those shown in Figure 6(b) while the boundaries of the stability regions are almost the same although they might appear narrower than those presented in Figure 6(b), which is caused by the difference in the delay limits. Analogous to Figure 6(b), the darker the shaded areas in Figure 7 the more damped the solution is. The numerical solution of Figure 7 are considered to be more pronounced as they were obtained from the full nonlinear equations. Figure 7.
Numerical nonlinear contour results of the reduction R as a function of Kv and γ when Kd = 0.2.

To illustrate the differences between the analytical linear solution and the numerical nonlinear solution, the optimal damping parameters for Kv > 0 obtained from Figures 6(b) and 7 are compared. Starting with the linear results of Figure 6(b), the maximum damping occurs at Kv = 0.276 and γ = 0.418, while the maximum damping obtained from the nonlinear results of Figure 7 occurs at Kv = 0.456 and γ = 0.455. To demonstrate these difference in a better way, the time responses corresponding to these two cases are plotted and presented in Figure 8. It is clearly seen from the figure that the two time-responses are somewhat different. Obviously, the optimal damping calculated analytically, using the linear analysis, causes the system to decay faster yet with a much higher overshoot than that obtained numerically by solving the nonlinear system. It is also clear that the linear solution consists of a single frequency while the numerical nonlinear solution consists of multiple frequencies. The existence of these multiple frequencies helped in reducing the overshoot by almost 50%, which in turn reduces the controller effort. This proves that the nonlinear numerical solution, Figure 7, provides a more precise mean of selecting the optimal combination of time delay, γ, and controller gain, Kv. This proves that solving the linear system of Equations (25) and (26) does not accurately capture the complete design space although it can accurately predict the stability boundaries. Hence, the linear solution cannot accurately predict the exact location of the maximum reduction and consequently the optimal gain and time delay combinations. Figure 8.
Time responses for the optimal damping calculated using analytical, linear, and numerical, nonlinear, analysis.

To show the complete boundaries of stability for this controller, the value of the damping parameter ζ in Equations (25) and (26) is set to zero and then the system is solved for Kd and γ while varying Kv. The result of this process is shown in a three-dimensional plot in Figure 9. It is clear that as the time delay γ increases, the design boundaries decrease resulting in less space for selecting optimal delay-gain combination. On the other hand, it is clear that for short time delay values, the stability design boundaries are larger; therefore, providing wider range of optimal delay-gain combination. This decrease in stability design boundaries is a known property of delay controllers (Masoud et al. 2004, 2005; Alhazza et al. 2008b, 2009). Figure 9 also shows that when the controller parameter Kd increases beyond 1 or Kv increases beyond 1.52 the system has no stable regions. Figure 9.
Three-dimensional stability design regions.

sec.title: 5. Numerical simulations
sec.p:
To demonstrate the adequacy of using the numerically obtained nonlinear results of Figure 7 for selecting the optimal delay-gain combinations, as compared with those obtained analytically using the linear theory, three sets of delay-gain combinations are chosen and their corresponding time responses are analyzed. It is clear from Figure 7 that as the time delay increases, the effectiveness of the controller diminishes. For a time delay, γ, less than 0.25, one can easily find a suitable gain-delay controller parameters that lead to excellent vibration attenuation. However, as γ increases, the range of controller gains that one can choose from for a good performance becomes limited. The time responses of these three sets are shown in Figures 10–12. These results are obtained for the beam shown in Figure 1 using a piezoelectric material, PZT PKI 502, beam of length l = 0.3 m; modulus of elasticity E = 70 GPa; mass density ρ = 2,700 kg m−3, width b = 0.02 m; and thickness tp = 0.2 mm and tb = 1 mm. The location of the PZT on the beam is defined by the initial and final positions s1 = 0.01 m and s2 = 0.08 m, respectively. Figure 10.
Computer simulations: the beam response and feedback signal for a controller delay γ = 0.1 and velocity gain Kv = −1.0 when Kd = 0.2. Figure 11.
Computer simulations: the beam response and feedback signal for a controller delay γ = 0.45 and velocity gain Kv = 0.4 when Kd = 0.2. Figure 12.
Computer simulations: the beam response and feedback signal for a controller delay γ = 1.28 and velocity gain Kv = 0.0 when Kd = 0.2.

The first set of gain-delay parameters is selected at time delay, γ, equal to 0.1 and a controller velocity gain Kv of −1.0. The time response of the beam corresponding to this set is shown in Figure 10. The results shown in this figure represent the amplitude of the tip vibration of the beam, as a function of time. It should be noted that the beam was vibrating freely until time t/T = 2 at which the controller was turned ON. Obviously the controller effectively eliminates the vibrations of the first mode in less than half a period, between δ = t/T = 2 and δ = 2.5. This prompt damping is a result of proper/optimal selection of delay-gain combination. Comparing this controller with the single input controllers, see Figure 3, shows that the proposed multi-input control method greatly improved the performance of the delayed feedback controllers.

The second set consists of a time delay, γ = 0.45 anda velocity gain Kv = 0.4 (see Figure 7). Results show significant reduction in the amplitude of oscillations; however, it takes a longer time to produce the same attenuation as obtained by the first set of gain-delay control parameters. However, this set of delay-gain parameters results in a lower controller amplitude, meaning that the controller is consuming less effort. Such parameters can be used in situations where short time delay, as used in the first set, is not achievable and/or power supplies are limited. These situation can occur when using slow controller circuits.

The third set consists of a time delay, γ = 1.28 andvelocity gain Kv = 0. As in the second set (Figure 11), results in Figure 12 show that a longer time is required to achieve a vibration reduction comparable to that of the first set, which in turn means that much lower control effort is required. This becomes handy when working with systems that have limited control authority. In this case, the second and the third modeswere plotted to show that, for free vibrations, these modes are slightly excited and the effect of such excitation is negligible inside the stability regions, Figure 6(b).

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: A multi-input single-output delayed-feedback controller has been developed to reduce the nonlinear vibrations of a flexible beam using a single piezoelectric actuator. Several SISO delayed feedback controllers have been studied and analyzed. For each case, linear analysis of the closed-loop system produced two nonlinear algebraic equations that can be solved to determine the system behavior. The results obtained using linear analysis have been compared with those obtainedusing long-time integration of the nonlinear model. The optimal performance parameters of each controller have been found and then used to predict the behavior of the system. To enhance the delayed-feedback controller performance, a new multi-input single-output controller has been proposed and implemented. A three-dimensional figure showing the damping magnitude and system stability as a function of the controller gains and delay have been generated. The effectiveness of the new controller has been tested using several numerical simulations. Results obtained proved the feasibility of such a control approach in improving the performance of delay feedback controllers.
